subject: RE: [junit] How to test console output?
msgSnippet: ... We once had the requirement that there is *no* output on the console (but there was). We used a similar approach to write a failing test and then replaced
messageBody:
Brett Neumeier wrote:

> I agree with both of J. B.'s points above. However, at some
> points in the past I have been obligated to use class
> libraries that write to System.out, and which I cannot
> change. So, to test code that uses these libraries, I've
> found that I get a lot of mileage out of creating a little
> "ConsoleTester" helper class, which appears below. The basic
> idea is, in my unit test I create a ConsoleTester, then
> exercise the code I want to test, then get the output that
> was written to System.out from the ConsoleTester and make assertions
> about it.
>
> Again, please do not misunderstand: I don't like this
> approach. In my own code, I do not write to System.out, and
> I recommend that others avoid doing so as well.

We once had the requirement that there is *no* output on the console
(but there was). We used a similar approach to write a failing test and
then replaced all System.out's with logging until the test passed...

Regards, Ilja
